title: U.S. stock futures up slightly after strong retail sales
text:
Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average YM00 rose 75 points, or 0.2%, to 36,084.

Futures on the S&P 500 ES00 were up 5 points, or 0.1%, at 4,684.

Futures on the Nasdaq-100 NQ00 edged up 19.25 points, or 0.1%, to 16,207.

On Monday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, the S&P 500 SPX and Nasdaq Composite COMP each ended fractionally lower. The Russell 2000 RUT index saw a steeper loss of 0.5%.

What's driving markets

Retail sales jumped 1.7% in October, the government said, surpassing forecasts for a 1.5% rise and logging the biggest gain March when households received billions in federal stimulus money.

Meanwhile, with bond yields at three-week highs, inflation worries remained at the forefront.

“Uncertainty about the persistence of higher inflation continues to dog investor sentiment amid ongoing speculation about the timing of interest rate hikes by the world's major central banks,” said Raffi Boyadjian, lead investment analyst at XM.A “The stronger-than-expected jump in the New York Fed's manufacturing gauge on Monday was the latest data point to highlight long-lasting supply disruptions and rising costs, giving Treasury yields a nudge up.”

Third-quarter results from retail heavyweights and others were also rolling in as third quarter earnings reporting season hits the final stretch. Gains for shares of Dow components Home Depot Inc.HD and Walmart Inc. WMT were seen buoying the blue-chip gauge.

Which companies are in focus?

Home Depot shares rose in premarket trade after the home improvement retailer reported fiscal third-quarter profit, net sales and same-store sales that beat expectations.

Shares of Walmart jumped after the retail giant raised its full-year earnings guidance for a third consecutive quarter.
